io.github.ddimitrov.nuggets

Class Extractors

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.ddimitrov.nuggets.Extractors

  • public class Extractors
extends Object

    Entry Point Provides utilities for circumventing Java encapsulation, as well as building blocks for custom dependency injection. All functions provided by this class are threadsafe.

    Breaking Encapsulation

    If you need to access non-public or final members of a class, you may use peekField(target, targetType, fieldName, valueType) and pokeField(target, class, fieldName, value) to bypass the Java encapsulation with minimal fuss.

    To access static members, just pass null for target. If you need to access instance fields, you may skip the targetType parameter and it will be assumed to be actual class of the target parameter.

    
 // get access to Unsafe
 public static final Unsafe UNSAFE = Extractors.peekField(Unsafe.class, null, "theUnsafe", Unsafe.class);

 // swap the date format of existing object
 SimpleDateFormat sdf = Extractors.peekField(service, "dateFormat", SimpleDateFormat.class);
 Extractors.pokeField(sdf, "pattern", "yyyy/MM/dd");

    In case you need to access shadowed fields (i.e., field with the same name defined multiple times in the inheritance hierarchy, make sure you specify targetType to be a class where the field is declared (or at least visible according to the Java rules).

    Both peek/pokeField() are going through the full reflection API to resolve the field and assert security permissions for breaking the encapsulation. If you are repeatedly accessing the same fields, you can improve the performance at the expense of slightly more verbose code by using getAccessibleField(type, fieldName, checkSuperclasses) directly as follows:

    
 // cache these
 private static final Field dateFormatField = Extractors.getAccessibleField(MyService.class, "dateFormat", true);
 private static final Field formatPatternField = Extractors.getAccessibleField(SimpleDateFormat.class, "pattern", true);

 // swap the date format of existing object (fast)
 try {
     SimpleDateFormat sdf = (SimpleDateFormat) dateFormatField.get(service));
     formatPatternField.set(sdf, "yyyy/MM/dd");
 } catch (IllegalAccessException e) {
     Exceptions.rethrow(e);
 }

    Instantiation and injection utils

    Sometimes, especially when we write a library, we may need to provide some functionality if certain library is present and provide a fall-back or even omit it, if it isn't. This is easy to do by using getClassIfPresent(className): 

    
 templateResolver = Extractors.getClassIfPresent("groovy.lang.GroovyObject")
     ? new GroovyTemplateResolver()
     : new SimpleResolver("${", "}");

    At times we would like some kind of DI functionality, but without bringing in a full-blown DI container, such as Guice, Dagger or Pico. This is when findInjectableConstructor(boolean, Constructor...) and findInjectableMethods(Method...) come handy. Once you find the things you want to invoke, you may easily assemble a signature using autowireByType(Executable, Function) as follows:

    
 public class SimpleDi {
     private Map<Class, Object> instances = new HashMap<>();
 
     public <T> void bindSingleton(Class<T> type, T implementation)  {
         instances.put(type, implementation);
     }
 
     public <T> Collection<T> instancesOf(Class<T> type) {
         return instances.values().stream()
                         .filter(it -> type.isAssignableFrom(it.getClass()))
                         .map(type::cast)
                         .collect(Collectors.toSet());
     }
 
     public <T> T instantiate(Class<T> type) throws IllegalAccessException, InvocationTargetException, InstantiationException {
         if (instances.containsKey(type)) { //noinspection unchecked
             return (T) instances.get(type);
         } else {
             instances.put(type, null); // prevent instantiation loops
         }
 
         Function<Class<?>, Object> paramResolver = t -> Exceptions.rethrow(() -> {
             Object defaultValue = Extractors.defaultValue(t);
             return defaultValue == null ? instantiate(t) : defaultValue;
         });
 
         if ((type.getModifiers() & (Modifier.ABSTRACT | Modifier.INTERFACE)) != 0) {
             throw new InstantiationException("Only concrete classes supported!");
         }
         // instantiate object
         Constructor<T> constructor = Extractors.findInjectableConstructor(false, type.getConstructors());
         Object[] args = Extractors.autowireByType(constructor, paramResolver);
         T instance = constructor.newInstance(args);
         instances.put(type, instance);
 
         // call methods annotated with @Inject
         for (Method method : Extractors.findInjectableMethods(type.getMethods())) {
             method.invoke(instance, Extractors.autowireByType(method, paramResolver));
         }
 
         return instance; // fully constructed and initialized
     }
 } *
 ...
 // usage to bootstrap an app with plugin strategies and lifecycle management
 di = new SimpleDi();
 xyzzy = new XyzzyServiceImpl();
 di.bindSingleton(IXyzzyService.class, xyzzy);
 di.bindSingleton(IFooBarStrategy.class, new FooBarLocalImpl());
 app = di.instantiate(Application.class);
 di.instancesOf(XyzzyListener.class).forEach(it -> xyzzy.addListener(it))
 app.run();
 di.instancesOf(Closeable.class).forEach(Closeable::close);
 app.shutdown();

    • Method Detail

      • peekField

        @Contract(pure=true)
public static <T> T peekField(@NotNull
                                                   @NotNull Object target,
                                                   @NotNull
                                                   @NotNull String fieldName,
                                                   @NotNull
                                                   @NotNull Class<T> fieldType)

        Extract the value of an instance field regardless of its visibility. If there are multiple shadowed fields with the given name, return the value of the first found when traversing the inheritance hierarchy starting from the type, until Object.

        If you are looking to extract a static field, or would like to get the value of a shadowed field, use the overloaded peekField(Object, Class, String, Class)

        Type Parameters:
        T - inferring the return type.
        Parameters:
        target - the object containing the data.
        fieldName - the name of the field to extract.
        fieldType - the expected type of the returned value.
        Returns:
        the extracted value of the requested field
        See Also:
        getAccessibleField(Class, String, boolean), peekField(Object, String, Class)

      • peekField

        @Contract(pure=true)
public static <T> T peekField(@Nullable
                                                   @Nullable Object target,
                                                   @NotNull
                                                   @NotNull Class<?> type,
                                                   @NotNull
                                                   @NotNull String fieldName,
                                                   @NotNull
                                                   @NotNull Class<T> fieldType)

        Extract the value of a field regardless of its visibility. If there are multiple shadowed fields with the given name, return the value of the first found when traversing the inheritance hierarchy starting from the type, until Object.

        Type Parameters:
        T - inferring the return type.
        Parameters:
        target - the object containing the data. null if we are looking to extract a static field.
        type - the type from which to start the search for the field. See getAccessibleField(type, name, true) for the precise meaning.
        fieldName - the name of the field to extract.
        fieldType - the expected type of the returned value. Needs to be a boxed (non-primitive) type.
        Returns:
        the extracted value of the requested field.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the fieldType is a primitive type.
        See Also:
        getAccessibleField(Class, String, boolean), peekField(Object, String, Class)

      • pokeField

        public static void pokeField(@NotNull
                             @NotNull Object target,
                             @NotNull
                             @NotNull String fieldName,
                             @Nullable
                             @Nullable Object value)

        Modify the value of an instance field regardless of its visibility or final modifier. If there are multiple shadowed fields with the given name, set the value of the first found when traversing the inheritance hierarchy starting from the type, until Object.

        If you are looking to set a static field, or would like to set the value of a shadowed field, use the overloaded pokeField(Object, Class, String, Object)

        Parameters:
        target - the object on which to set the field. null if we are looking to set a static field.
        fieldName - the name of the field to set.
        value - the new value to set.
        See Also:
        getAccessibleField(Class, String, boolean), peekField(Object, String, Class), pokeField(Object, Class, String, Object)

      • pokeField

        public static void pokeField(@Nullable
                             @Nullable Object target,
                             @NotNull
                             @NotNull Class<?> type,
                             @NotNull
                             @NotNull String fieldName,
                             @Nullable
                             @Nullable Object value)

        Modify the value of a field regardless of its visibility or final modifier. If there are multiple shadowed fields with the given name, set the value of the first found when traversing the inheritance hierarchy starting from the type, until Object.

        Parameters:
        target - the object on which to set the field. null if we are looking to set a static field.
        type - the type from which to start the search for the field. See getAccessibleField(type, name, true) for the precise meaning.
        fieldName - the name of the field to set.
        value - the new value to set.
        See Also:
        getAccessibleField(Class, String, boolean), peekField(Object, Class, String, Class), pokeField(Object, String, Object)

      • getAccessibleField

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull Field getAccessibleField(@NotNull
                                                                               @NotNull Class<?> type,
                                                                               @NotNull
                                                                               @NotNull String fieldName,
                                                                               boolean checkSuperclasses)

        Gets a Field instance that can be used to get and set values, regardless of the field visibility, final or static modifiers. Subject to security policy restrictions (if you don't know what that is, don't worry - you are probably safe).

        Sometimes there would be multiple fields with the same name declared in parent and sub-classes. In such cases make sure you specify the type of the exact class you want to get the field from.

        Parameters:
        type - the type or a subtype of the class that holds the field.
        fieldName - the name of the field we want.
        checkSuperclasses - if false, will check only type; if true, will check type and it's super classes all the way up to Object.
        Returns:
        the writable field instance
        Throws:
        NoSuchFieldException - if the field could not be found in the searched classes.
        See Also:
        peekField(Object, String, Class), pokeField(Object, String, Object), AccessibleObject.setAccessible(boolean)

      • unboxClass

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull Class<?> unboxClass(@NotNull
                                                                          @NotNull Class<?> type)
        Converts Java boxed classes (java.lang.Void, java.lang.Integer, java.lang.Character, etc.) to their primitive peers. If the type is already primitive, it is returned as is. Array classes are returned as-is (that may change in the future).
        Parameters:
        type - a class to convert
        Returns:
        the corresponding primitive class

      • boxClass

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull Class<?> boxClass(@NotNull
                                                                        @NotNull Class<?> type)
        Converts primitive Java classes (void.class, char.class, int.class) to their boxed (java.lang.Void, java.lang.Character, java.lang.Integer, etc.) If the type is not a primitive primitive, it will be returned as is. Array classes are returned as-is (that may change in the future).
        Parameters:
        type - a class to convert
        Returns:
        the corresponding primitive class

        Parameters:

public static <T> T defaultValue(@NotNull

        Provides default value for each type, such as false, zero, empty array, no-args constructed instance, or null if there is no no-arg constructor or it threw exception.
        Type Parameters:

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • findInjectableConstructor

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static <T> @NotNull Constructor<T> findInjectableConstructor(boolean requireAnnotation,
                                                                                                   @NotNull
                                                                                                   Constructor<?>... candidates)

        Finds the best constructor for dependency injection instantiation, based on number of arguments and @Injected annotation. If at least one candidate is annotated with Injected or the requireAnnotation==true, then only annotated candidates will be considered. Otherwise, return the candidates with largest number of formal arguments.


        Example: find the most suitable constructor for DI (annotated with Inject, or largest number of params):

        
 Constructor<FooBar> fbc = Extractors.findInjectableConstructor(false, FooBar.class.getConstructors());
 FooBar foobar = fbc.newInstance(Extractors.autowireByType(fbc, Extractors::defaultValue));
        Type Parameters:
        T - inferring the return type.
        Parameters:
        requireAnnotation - if true, consider only candidates annotated with @Inject
        candidates - list of constructors to consider. In practice we expect an array of Constructor<T>, though the actual arg is declared as Constructor<T> so it can be used without warnings with the return value of Class.getConstructors().
        Returns:
        the most suitable constructor (most params, or annotated with @Inject)
        See Also:
        autowireByType(Executable, Function), findInjectableMethods(Method...)

      • findInjectableMethods

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull Method[] findInjectableMethods(@NotNull
                                                                                     Method... candidates)

        Finds candidates for method dependency injection, based on @Injected annotation.

        Example: Find all methods annotated with Inject and invoke them:

        
 for (Executable m : Extractors.findInjectableCandidates(foobar.getClass().geMethods())) {
      m.invoke(foobar, Extractors.autowireByType(m, Extractors::defaultValue))
 }
        Parameters:
        candidates - list of methods to consider.
        Returns:
        all candidates annotated with @Inject)
        See Also:
        findInjectableConstructor(boolean, java.lang.reflect.Constructor<?>...), findInjectableCandidates(boolean, Predicate, Executable[]), autowireByType(Executable, Function)

      • findInjectableCandidates

        @SafeVarargs
 @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static <T extends Executable> T[] findInjectableCandidates(boolean requireAnnotation,
                                                                                                               @Nullable
                                                                                                               @Nullable Predicate<T> filter,
                                                                                                               @NotNull
                                                                                                               T... candidates)

        Finds constructors or methods for dependency injection, based on the number of arguments and @Injected annotation. If at least one candidate is annotated with Injected or the requireAnnotation==true, then only annotated candidates will be considered. Otherwise, return the candidates with largest number of formal arguments.


        Example: find the most suitable constructor for DI (annotated with Inject, or largest number of params):

        
 Constructor<FooBar> fbc = Extractors.findInjectableCandidates(false, FooBar.class.getConstructors());
 FooBar foobar = fbc.newInstance(Extractors.autowireByType(fbc, Extractors::defaultValue));
        Type Parameters:
        T - inferring the constructor or method type.
        Parameters:
        requireAnnotation - if true, consider only candidates annotated with @Inject
        filter - if not null and returns false for a candidate, the candidate is excluded
        candidates - list of constructors to consider. In practice we expect an array of Constructor<T>, though the actual arg is declared as Constructor<T> so it can be used without warnings with the return value of Class.getConstructors().
        Returns:
        the most suitable constructor (most params, or annotated with @Inject)
        See Also:
        findInjectableConstructor(boolean, Constructor[]), findInjectableMethods(Method...), autowireByType(Executable, Function)

      • autowireByType

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull Object[] autowireByType(@NotNull
                                                                              @NotNull Executable ctorOrMethod,
                                                                              @NotNull
                                                                              @NotNull Function<Class<?>,Object> paramResolver)
        Provide arguments to invoke a method or constructor, based on signature types and resolver function. Can be used to call arguments with null params, or implement simple DI layer.
        Parameters:
        ctorOrMethod - the constructor or method to call.
        paramResolver - mapping function from type to implementation value can be as simple as Map::get.
        Returns:
        the signature array.
